caption.p: Overview of proteins from grain legumes glycated with various carbohydrates under different reaction conditions and their functionalities.

tr.th: Ratio w/ w (If Not Stated Otherwise)

tr.td: Increased antimicrobial activity and emulsifying properties; decreased allergenicity
Increased gel-like rheological behavior and emulsion stability against coalescence and creaming
Increased emulsion stability after prolonged heating
dry: 1:1; wet: 1:4/14/30/52/74 molar ratio of NH 2 to carbohydrate
dry: demineralized water, pH 7.4; wet: 0.5 M phosphate buffer, pH 7.4
1:52 molar ratio of NH 2 to carbohydrate
Glycation did not change antioxidant activity of soy protein
tofu whey, acid precipitated soy protein, glycinin, β-conglycinin
galactomannan, okara polysaccharides, xyloglucan, chitin, chitosan oligosaccharides
0.5 mM phosphate buffer and distilled water, pH 7
Increased emulsification activity and emulsion stability; high or low oil/water binding capacities depending on carbohydrate
Increased hydrophilicity and emulsifying properties (against pH changes, heat treatment, and long-term storage)
Increased heat stability and emulsifying properties; no change of solubility but maintained after heat treatment
60 °C, 24 h, over KBr solution, afterwards 55 °C, 6 h in oven
Increased water absorption capacities, emulsifying properties, and foaming properties; decreased oil absorption capacities
Increased stability against thermal aggregation at various pH or ionic strength values
distilled water, ethanol addition for wet heating
dry: 60 °C, 1–7 days, 79% RH; wet: 50 and 60 °C, 6 and 24 h
Increased solubility, heat stability and emulsifying properties (against heat treatment and ionic stress), ethanol enhanced glycation
Increased solubility (at various pH, heat treatment, and ionic stress), and emulsifying properties (against various pH, ionic stress, and heat treatment)
Increased antioxidant activities and flavor (increased caramel-like, soy sauce-like, umami, and mouthful taste, reduced bitterness)
Increased solubility, macromolecular crowding conditions prompt glycation and prevent thermal aggregation
Optimization of reaction conditions to achieve maximum degree of glycation
fenugreek gum, partially hydrolyzed fenugreek gum

Increased emulsifying properties, encapsulation efficiency of oil in spray-dried emulsions, and redispersion and dissolution properties; decreased apparent viscosity of emulsions and storage stability of spray-dried emulsions
60 °C, 3 days for maltodextrin, 1 week for gum acacia, over KBr solution
Increased solubility and emulsifying properties; decreased surface hydrophobicity
Increased heat stability, structural flexibility, and emulsifying properties; macromolecular crowding conditions enhanced glycation
Increased solubility, heat stability; decreased surface hydrophobicity; denser gels with higher elastic modulus
Increased heat stability, antioxidant activities, and emulsifying properties
dextran (20 kDa, 40 kDa), maltose, lactose, glucose, galactose
Increased emulsifying properties (against pH changes, thermal treatment, ionic stress, and storage stability)
Increased emulsifying properties and foaming properties
Increased emulsifying properties for citral-loaded emulsions (enhanced stability during storage, after heat treatment or under simulated gastrointestinal conditions)
Increased encapsulation properties for citral-loaded emulsions (protection and targeted delivery)
Increased emulsifying properties; encapsulation of tomato oleoresin in spray-dried emulsions; protection of lycopene in particles against light, humidity, and temperature
95 °C, 15 min, ultrasonication at 200 W (138.26 W/cm 2) for 20 min
Ultrasonication enhances glycation and eliminates the weakening effect of glycation on gel network of acid-induced protein gel
Increased emulsion viscosity/shear thinning and emulsifying properties
Increased surface properties of conjugates as result of strong membrane formed by closely packed molecular and multilayer adsorption at interface, and emulsifying properties
Increased or decreased immunoreactivity of glycated protein depending on the blood serum used
Increased heat stability, solubility, water holding capacity antioxidant properties, and emulsifying properties; spray-dried conjugate powders had better reconstitution properties
Increased emulsifying properties (against heat treatment, over prolonged storage)
wet with ultrasound or microwave assistance
ultrasound: 80 °C, 25 kHz, 500 W, 40 min; microwave: 2450 MHz, 800 W, 2 min
Increased encapsulation properties for B. Longum in freeze-dried or spray-dried microcapsules; protection against pasteurization and simulated gastrointestinal digestion
Increased antioxidant properties and sensory characteristics (increased umami taste, decreased bitterness)
Increased emulsifying properties with chitosan oligosaccharide
85–125 °C, 1.5–2.5 h, in some cases pressure application
Increased water/oil binding capacities and emulsifying properties; decreased surface hydrophobicity, in vitro digestibility, and thermal stability
soy protein isolate and enzymatically hydrolyzed soy protein isolate
Increased emulsifying properties (against pH changes), freeze–thaw stability of emulsions
Increased foaming properties and emulsifying properties; changes were positively correlated with molecular flexibility
Increased emulsifying properties; molecular flexibility can be indicator for emulsifying properties
wet: water, pH 6–12; ultrasound: water, pH 10
wet with and without ultrasound assistance
Increased molecular flexibility, surface hydrophobicity, and emulsifying properties; ultrasound treatment accelerated glycation
Increased solubility and emulsifying properties; decreased surface hydrophobicity
wet: water, pH 10; ultrasound: water, pH 7–12
wet and slit divergent ultrasonic-assisted wet heating

Increased surface hydrophobicity, solubility, thermal stability, viscosity, foaming properties, and emulsifying properties (against pH changes, thermal treatment, and ionic stress); ultrasonic treatment enhanced glycation
Increased solubility; moderate pressure promotes glycation
Encapsulation of capsaicin in nanoemulsions; increased pH/thermal/storage stability of emulsions; decreased mean particle diameter
Findings suggest fractionating the complex reaction mixture for analyzing and different functionalities
Increased thermal stability and Pickering emulsion stabilization
Increased solubility, thermal stability, water/fat absorption capacity, foaming properties, and emulsifying properties; irradiation is highly efficient and affordable
200 W (20 kHz) for 5–25 min pretreatment, 95 °C, 30 min
Ultrasonic treatment promotes glycation; increased surface hydrophobicity; decreased acid-induced gelation properties; gel quality of ultrasonicated conjugates better
Positive effect on growth of gut commensal bacteria (lactobacilli and bifidobacteria)
Increased solubility and emulsifying properties (physical stability against pH changes, temperature and ionic stress and chemical stability against lipid oxidation)
Increased solubility, surface hydrophilicity, and emulsifying properties (physical stability against pH changes and chemical stability against lipid oxidation); decrease of beany flavor markers
Increased interfacial tension and emulsifying properties (against pH changes)
Increased solubility and emulsifying properties (against pH changes, ionic stress, and heat treatment); decrease of beany flavor markers
Increased solubility and surface hydrophilicity; decreased thermal stability and beany flavor
soluble fraction of pea protein isolate
Increased solubility and emulsifying properties (against pH changes, ionic stress, and storage at elevated temperatures); decreased lutein color degradation in emulsions
Increased surface hydrophobicity, molecular flexibility, emulsification activity, and emulsion stability; decreased solubility
Increased apparent viscosity, shear thinning, and yield stress
Decreased solubility; good properties when used in bread/cake dough
Ultrasonication enhanced glycation; increased solubility, emulsification activity, and emulsion stability; decreased surface hydrophobicity
Increased solubility, emulsification activity, and emulsion stability; decreased surface hydrophobicity
No big influence on rheological properties and gel stability/stiffness
partially hydrolyzed black bean protein isolate
Increased solubility, antioxidant activity, emulsification activity, and emulsion stability; decreased surface hydrophobicity
black bean protein isolate, ultrasound pretreatment
Increased solubility, surface hydrophobicity, antioxidant activity, emulsification activity, and emulsion stability
Increased solubility, surface hydrophobicity, emulsifying properties (during storage and against ionic stress), and foaming properties
Potential allergenicity of Maillard reaction products
fried at 120 °C, 5 min; roasted at 170 °C, 20 min
Oxidative lipid degradation in peanuts may affect lysine derivatization
Increased thermal stability, solubility, emulsifying properties, and foaming properties
Increased solubility and emulsifying properties; decreased surface hydrophobicity; conjugate structure more flexible and less compact
Ultrasound enhanced glycation; increased solubility and emulsifying properties
Ultrasound enhanced glycation; increased solubility and emulsifying properties
Increased tensile strength, elongation, and water resistance; decreased solubility
Ultrasound enhanced glycation; increased solubility and emulsifying properties
Increased surface hydrophobicity, tensile strength, and elongation; decreased solubility
peanut protein isolate, hydrolysate and fractions thereof
Increased umami taste and umami-enhancing properties
60 °C, subsequent plasma treatment at 35 V and 2 A for 0–3 min
Plasma treatment enhanced glycation; increased solubility and emulsifying properties
80 °C, 40 min, subsequent plasma treatment at 90 W for 0–5 min
Increased thermal stability; decreased surface hydrophobicity and protein enthalpy

fn.p: RH: relative humidity, PBS: phosphate-buffered saline.
